article.title: DuckDuckGo
article.text:
{{about|the search engine|the children's game|Duck, duck, goose}}

{{Infobox website
| name = DuckDuckGo
| logo = [[File:DuckDuckGo logo and wordmark (2014-present).svg|150px]]
| screenshot = 
| caption = Screenshot of DuckDuckGo [[home page]] as of August, 2017
| url = {{URL|https://duckduckgo.com}}
| slogan = The search engine that doesn't track you.
| commercial = Yes
| type = [[Web search engine]]
| registration = None
| language = Multilingual
| programming language = [[Perl]],<ref name="Buys"/> [[JavaScript]], [[Python (programming language)|Python]]<ref name="duckduckgo-architecture">{{cite web|url=https://duck.co/help/company/architecture|title=Architecture|work=DuckDuckGo Community Platform|accessdate=March 6, 2015}}</ref>
| owner = Duck Duck Go, Inc.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=141641872 |title=Duck Duck Go, Inc.: Private Company Information |accessdate=2 May 2017 |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]] }}</ref>
| author = Gabriel Weinberg
| launch date = {{start date and age|2008|9|25}}
| revenue = 
| alexa = {{Increase}}292<small>({{as of|2018|04|18|alt=April 18, 2018}})</small><ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= https://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/duckduckgo.com |title= Duckduckgo.com Traffic Statistics | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 18 April 2018}}</ref>
| current status = Active
| location = 20 Paoli Pike, [[Paoli, Pennsylvania]], [[United States]]
| area_served = Worldwide
| headquarters = 20 Paoli Pike, Paoli, Pennsylvania, USA
}}

'''DuckDuckGo''' ('''DDG''') is an Internet [[web search engine|search engine]] that emphasizes protecting searchers' [[internet privacy|privacy]] and avoiding the [[filter bubble]] of personalized search results.<ref name="Buys" /> DuckDuckGo distinguishes itself from other search engines by not profiling its users and by deliberately showing all users the same search results for a given search term,<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://dontbubble.us/|title = dontbubble.us|date = |accessdate = 2014-09-12|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> and emphasizes returning the best results, rather than the most results, generating those results from over 400 individual sources, including [[Crowdsourcing|crowdsourced]] sites such as [[Wikipedia]], and other search engines like [[Bing (search engine)|Bing]], [[Yahoo! Search BOSS|Yahoo!]], and [[Yandex Search|Yandex]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Sources|url=https://duck.co/help/results/sources|website=DuckDuckGo Help pages|publisher=DuckDuckGo|accessdate=2017-04-29|deadurl=yes|archivedate=2015-01-24|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150124074006/https://duck.co/help/results/sources}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2014/06/11/duckduckgo-yummly-team-up-so-you-can-search-food-porn-in-private/ |title=DuckDuckGo & Yummly team up so you can search food porn in private |publisher=VentureBeat |date=June 11, 2014 |accessdate=June 11, 2014}}</ref>

The company is based in [[Paoli, Pennsylvania]], in [[Greater Philadelphia]], and has 40 employees. The company name originates from the children's game [[duck, duck, goose]].<ref name="WashPostNov2012">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/ducking-google-in-search-engines/2012/11/09/6cf3af10-2842-11e2-bab2-eda299503684_story.html|title=Ducking Google in search engines|work=[[The Washington Post]]|first=Michael|last=Rosenwald|date=November 9, 2012|accessdate=March 19, 2013}}</ref><ref name=Arthur>Arthur, Charles. "[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/10/nsa-duckduckgo-gabriel-weinberg-prism NSA scandal delivers record numbers of internet users to DuckDuckGo]." ''[[The Guardian]]''. July 10, 2013. Retrieved July 10, 2013.</ref>

Some of DuckDuckGo's source code is [[free software]] hosted at [[GitHub]] under the [[Apache License|Apache 2.0 License]],<ref name="Githubduckduckgo">{{cite web|url = https://github.com/duckduckgo/duckduckgo|title = duckduckgo |publisher = GitHub Inc|date = March 16, 2012|accessdate = March 19, 2012}}</ref> but the core is proprietary. The company registered the domain names ''ddg.gg'' on 22 February 2011 and ''ddg.co'' on 20 September 2013 which are used as shortened URL aliases that redirect to ''duckduckgo.com''. On 21 May 2014, DuckDuckGo launched a redesigned version that focused on smarter answers and a more refined look. The new version added often requested features such as images, local search, auto-suggest and more.<ref name="DuckDuckGo Reimagined & Redesigned">{{cite web|url=https://duck.co/blog/post/84/whatsnew |title=DuckDuckGo Reimagined & Redesigned}}</ref>

On 18 September 2014, [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] included DuckDuckGo in its [[Safari (web browser)|Safari]] browser as an optional search engine.<ref name="Big Win For DuckDuckGo">{{cite web|url=http://searchengineland.com/big-win-duckduckgo-apple-adding-safari-private-search-option-193081 |title=Big Win For DuckDuckGo: Apple Adding To Safari As Private Search Option |accessdate=2014-09-30}}</ref><ref name="Apple - OS X Yosemite - Apps">{{cite web|url=https://www.apple.com/osx/preview/apps/ |title=Apple - OS X Yosemite - Apps |accessdate=2014-09-30}}</ref> On 10 November 2014, [[Mozilla]] added DuckDuckGo as a search option to [[Firefox]] 33.1.<ref>{{cite web|title=Firefox Notes|url=https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/33.1/releasenotes/|website=Mozilla.org|accessdate=11 November 2014}}</ref> On 30 May 2016, [[The Tor Project, Inc]] made DuckDuckGo the default search engine for [[Tor (anonymity network)#Tor Browser|Tor Browser]] 6.0.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/05/31/tor-switches-to-duckduckgo-search-results-by-default/ |title=Tor switches to DuckDuckGo search results by default |accessdate=2017-09-25 |publisher=TechCrunch}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.searchenginejournal.com/duckduckgo-becomes-default-search-provider-tor-browser/165098/ |title=DuckDuckGo Becomes Default Search Provider for Tor Browser |accessdate=2017-09-25 |publisher=Search Engine Journal}}</ref><ref>{{Webbref |url=https://blog.torproject.org/blog/tor-browser-60-released |title=Tor Browser 6.0 is released |accessdate=2017-09-25 |date=2016-05-30 |publisher=The Tor Blog}}</ref>

== History ==
DuckDuckGo was founded in 2008<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3026698/inside-duckduckgo-googles-tiniest-fiercest-competitor |date=February 20, 2014 |title=Inside DuckDuckGo, Google's Tiniest, Fiercest Competitor |first=John Paul |last=Titlow |publisher=Fast Company |accessdate=December 4, 2016}}</ref> by Gabriel Weinberg,<ref>{{cite web|title=Company History |date=June 3, 2013|url=http://help.dukgo.com/customer/portal/articles/216406-history |publisher=Duckduckgo.com |accessdate=August 8, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Search Engine and Privacy by Gabriel Weinberg |url=http://www.eyerys.com/articles/people/search-engine-and-privacy-gabriel-weinberg |publisher=Eyerys |accessdate=March 14, 2015 }}</ref> an entrepreneur who previously launched [[Names Database]], a now-defunct social network. Initially self-funded by Weinberg, DuckDuckGo is now{{when|date=June 2017}} [[advertising]]-supported but the user has the option to disable ads.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://chouprojects.com/duckduckgo-search-engine/|title=Duck Duck Go Startup Profile |publisher=Chouprojects.com|accessdate = January 28, 2014}}</ref> The search engine is written in [[Perl]]<ref name="Perl">{{cite web|url = https://github.com/duckduckgo/duckduckgo/wiki/DuckDuckGoPerl |title = DuckDuckGoPerl · duckduckgo/duckduckgo Wiki · GitHub |publisher=Github |accessdate = May 10, 2016 }}</ref> and runs on [[nginx]], [[FreeBSD]] and [[Linux]].<ref name="Buys">{{cite web|url = http://ostatic.com/blog/duckduckgo-a-new-search-engine-built-from-open-source|title = DuckDuckGo: A New Search Engine Built from Open Source|last = Buys|first = Jon|date = July 10, 2010|publisher = GigaOM OStatic blog|accessdate = March 19, 2013|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110317053629/http://ostatic.com/blog/duckduckgo-a-new-search-engine-built-from-open-source|archivedate = March 17, 2011|df = }}</ref><ref name="Weinberg">{{cite web|url = http://duckduckgo.com/about.html|title = About Duck Duck Go|last = Weinberg|first = Gabriel |publisher=Duckduckgo.com|accessdate = February 10, 2011}}</ref><ref name="Architecture">{{cite web|url = http://help.duckduckgo.com/customer/portal/articles/216392-architecture|title = Architecture|date=January 28, 2013 |publisher=DuckDuckGo.com |accessdate= June 11, 2013}}</ref> DuckDuckGo is built primarily upon search [[Application programming interface|APIs]] from various vendors<!-- no need to call out one, if there are more than 50-->. Because of this, [[TechCrunch]] characterized the service as a "hybrid" search engine.<ref name="TCFriday">{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2008/12/12/elevator-pitch-friday-duck-duck-go-the-hybrid-search-engine/ |date=December 12, 2008 |title=Elevator Pitch Friday: Duck Duck Go, the Hybrid Search Engine |first=Dan |last=Kimerling |publisher=Techcrunch |accessdate=March 19, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=1217495|date=March 25, 2010 |title=Duck Duck Go is starting to get coverage (thread: see remarks by Weinberg)|first=Gabriel (as epi0Bauqu) |last=Weinberg |publisher=YCombinator Hacker News |accessdate=March 19, 2013}}</ref> At the same time, it produces its own content pages, and thus is similar to [[Mahalo.com|Mahalo]], [[Kosmix]] and [[SearchMe]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.crunchbase.com/company/duck-duck-go|title=Duck Duck Go Company Profile |publisher=Crunchbase.com }}{{dubious|reason=User generated content|date=March 2013}}{{failed verification|date=March 2013}}</ref> Weinberg explained the beginnings of the name with respect to the children's game [[duck, duck, goose]]. He said of the origin of the name, "Really it just popped in my head one day and I just liked it. It is certainly influenced/derived from duck duck goose, but other than that there is no relation, e.g., a metaphor."<!--no wikilinks in quotes--><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=652015|date=June 11, 2009 |title=How Often our Anti-spam Search Toolbar Blocks Sites (thread) |publisher=YCombinator Hacker News |last=Weinberg|first=Gabriel (as epi0Bauqu) |accessdate=March 19, 2013}}</ref> DuckDuckGo was featured on [[TechCrunch]]'s Elevator Pitch Friday in 2008,<ref name="TCFriday"/> and it was a finalist in the 2008 [[Yahoo! Search BOSS|BOSS]] [[Mashable]] Challenge.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://mashable.com/2008/10/07/voting-boss-mashable-challenge/ |date= October 7, 2008 |title=Voting Round for the BOSS Mashable Challenge|first= Adam |last=Hirsch |publisher=[[Mashable]] |accessdate=March 19, 2013}}</ref>

In July 2010, Weinberg started a DuckDuckGo community website (duck.co) to allow the public to report problems, discuss means of spreading the use of the search engine, request features, and discuss open sourcing the code.<ref name="Community">{{cite web|url = http://duck.co/|title = duck.co – The DuckDuckGo Community|last = Weinberg|first = Gabriel |date=July 2010|accessdate = July 21, 2010}}</ref>

In September 2011 DuckDuckGo hired its first employee, Caine Tighe.<ref name="Inbound Hiring">{{cite web|url = http://www.gabrielweinberg.com/blog/2011/09/inbound-hiring.html|title = Inbound Hiring|last = Weinberg|first = Gabriel|publisher=gabrielweinberg.com blog |date=September 30, 2011 |accessdate = March 19, 2013}}</ref> The next month, [[Union Square Ventures]] invested in DuckDuckGo. Union Square partner Brad Burnham stated, "We invested in DuckDuckGo because we became convinced that it was not only possible to change the basis of competition in search, it was time to do it."<ref name="Burnham13Oct11">{{cite web|url = http://www.usv.com/2011/10/duck-duck-go.php|title = Duck Duck Go |last = Burnham|first = Brad|publisher=Union Square Ventures blog |date=October 13, 2011|accessdate = October 14, 2011}}</ref> In addition, [[Trisquel]], [[Linux Mint]] and the [[Midori (web browser)|Midori]] web browser switched to use DuckDuckGo as their default search engine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://trisquel.info/en/issues/2608#comment-8213 |title=DuckDuckGo in Web Browser |publisher=Trisquel.info | author=Mithrandir|date= November 25, 2010 |accessdate=March 19, 2013}}</ref>
{{Quote box
 |quote = We didn't invest in it because we thought it would beat Google. We invested in it because there is a need for a private search engine. We did it for the Internet anarchists, people that hang out on [[Reddit]] and [[Hacker News]].
 |source = [[Fred Wilson (financier)|Fred Wilson]], 2012 [[TechCrunch Disrupt]] Conference in New York<ref name=Ludwig1>{{cite news|last=Ludwig|first=Sean|title=Fred Wilson: We invested in DuckDuckGo for the Reddit, Hacker News anarchists|url=https://venturebeat.com/2012/05/21/fred-wilson-duckduckgo-reddit-hacker-news/|newspaper=[[VentureBeat]]|date=May 21, 2012|accessdate=January 29, 2013}}</ref>
 |width = 30%
 |align= right
 }}

By May 2012, the search engine was attracting 1.5 million searches a day. Weinberg reported that it had earned {{US$|115000}} in revenue in 2011 and had three employees, plus a small number of contractors.<ref name="Farivar16May12">{{cite news|url = https://arstechnica.com/business/2012/05/private-the-search-engines-that-make-money-by-not-tracking-users/|title = Private: some search engines make money by not tracking users|last = Farivar|first = Cyrus|date = May 16, 2012| work = [[Ars Technica]]|accessdate = May 14, 2012}}</ref> [[Compete.com]] estimated 277,512 monthly visitors to the site in August 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://siteanalytics.compete.com/duckduckgo.com/?metric=uv |title=DuckDuckGo Analytics Profile |publisher=Compete.com }}{{failed verification|date=March 2013}}<!-- get a WebCitation capture for each As of date --></ref> On April 12, 2011, [[Alexa Internet|Alexa]] reported a 3-month growth rate of 51%.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://alexa.com/siteinfo/duckduckgo.com |title=DuckDuckGo Analytics Profile |publisher=Alexa.com}}<!-- get a WebCitation capture for each As of date --></ref> DuckDuckGo's own [[traffic statistics]] show that in August 2012 there were 1,393,644 visits per day, up from an average of 39,406 visits per day in April 2010 (the earliest data available).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://duckduckgo.com/traffic.html|title=DuckDuckGo Official traffic}}<!-- get a WebCitation capture for each As of date --></ref> In a lengthy profile in November 2012, the ''[[Washington Post]]'' indicated that searches on DuckDuckGo numbered up to 45,000,000 per month in October 2012. The article concluded "Weinberg's non-ambitious goals make him a particularly odd and dangerous competitor online. He can do almost everything that [[Google Search|Google]] or [[Bing (search engine)|Bing]] can't because it could damage their business models, and if users figure out that they like the DuckDuckGo way better, Weinberg could damage the big boys without even really trying. It's asymmetrical digital warfare, and his backers at Union Square Ventures say Google is vulnerable."<ref name="WashPostNov2012"/>

[[GNOME]] released [[Web (web browser)]] 3.10 on September 26, 2013, and starting with this version, the default search engine is DuckDuckGo.<ref name="gnomepeopleblog">{{cite news|url=https://people.gnome.org/~csaavedra/news-2013-08.html#D27|title=Claudio Saavedra's ChangeLog – August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://mail.gnome.org/archives/devel-announce-list/2013-September/msg00003.html|title=GNOME 3.10 Released|first=Matthias|last=Clasen|date=26 September 2013|publisher=GNOME mailing list|accessdate=26 September 2013}}</ref>

At its keynote speech at WWDC 2014, Apple announced that DuckDuckGo would be included as an option for search on both [[iOS 8]] and [[OS X Yosemite]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.in/Apple-Is-Getting-Serious-About-Search-But-It-Doesnt-Want-Googles-Help/articleshow/36007303.cms |title=DuckDuckGo In Apple OS |publisher=BusinessInsider |date= |accessdate=2014-06-06}}</ref>. On March 10, the [[Pale Moon (web browser)|Pale Moon]] web browser, starting with version 24.4.0, included DuckDuckGo as its default search engine, as well as listed it on the browser's homepage.<ref name=palemoonrelease>{{cite web|title=Pale Moon 24.4.0 Release Notes|url=https://www.palemoon.org/releasenotes-archived.shtml|website=Pale Moon|publisher=Moonchild Productions|accessdate=4 June 2015}}</ref> In May 2014, DuckDuckGo released a redesigned version to beta testers through DuckDuckHack.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://next.duckduckgo.com/ |title=DuckDuckGo |publisher=Next.duckduckgo.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-11}}</ref> On 21 May 2014, DuckDuckGo officially released the redesigned version that focused on smarter answers and a more refined look. The new version added many new features such as images, local search, auto-suggest, weather, recipes and more.<ref name="DuckDuckGo Reimagined & Redesigned"/>

in July 2016, DuckDuckGo officially announced the extension of its partnership with [[Yahoo! Search|Yahoo!]] that brought new features to all users of the search engine, including date filtering of results and additional site links. It also partners with Bing, Yandex and Wikipedia to produce results or make use of features offered. The company also confirmed that it does not share user information with partner companies, as has always been its policy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ghacks.net/2016/07/01/duckduckgo-yahoo-partnership/|title=DuckDuckGo extends Yahoo partnership|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/duckduckgo/comments/4lgda4/duckduckgo_is_using_yahoo_for_searches_now/|title=DuckDuckGo is using yahoo for searches now.|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>

== Overview ==
{{Expand section|date=November 2014}}

DuckDuckGo's results are a compilation of "over 400" sources,<ref name="Sources">{{cite news |url=http://help.duckduckgo.com/customer/portal/articles/216399-sources |date=January 8, 2013 |title=Sources |publisher=DuckDuckGo Support Center |accessdate=March 19, 2013}}</ref> including [[Yahoo! Search BOSS]]; [[Wikipedia]]; [[Wolfram Alpha]]; [[Bing (search engine)|Bing]]; its own [[Web crawler]] (the ''DuckDuckBot''); and others.<ref name="Buys" /><ref name="Sources"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.wolframalpha.com/2011/04/18/wolframalpha-and-duckduckgo-partner-on-api-binding-and-search-integration/ |date= April 18, 2011|title=Wolfram Alpha and DuckDuckGo Partner on API Binding and Search Integration |publisher=Wolframalpha.com }}</ref> It also uses data from [[Crowdsourcing|crowdsourced]] sites, including Wikipedia, to populate "Zero-click Info" boxes – grey boxes above the results that display topic summaries and related topics.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.duckduckgo.com/about.html |title=About Duck Duck Go |publisher=Duckduckgo.com}}</ref>

DuckDuckGo positions itself as a search engine that puts privacy first and as such it does not store IP addresses, does not log user information and uses cookies only when needed. Weinberg states "By default, DuckDuckGo does not collect or share personal information. That is our privacy policy in a nutshell." However, they do maintain logs of all search terms used.<ref>[http://duckduckgo.com/privacy.html "DDG Privacy"]. Duckduckgo.com.</ref>

Weinberg has refined the quality of his search engine results by deleting search results for companies he believes are ''[[content farm|content mills]]'', like [[Demand Media]]'s [[eHow]], which publishes 4000 articles per day produced by paid freelance writers, which Weinberg says is, "...low-quality content designed specifically to rank highly in Google's search index." DuckDuckGo also filters pages with substantial advertising.<ref name="Mims26Jul10">{{cite web|url = http://www.technologyreview.com/blog/post.aspx?bid=377&bpid=25532|title = The Search Engine Backlash Against 'Content Mills'|last = Mims|first = Christopher|work=[[Technology Review]] |date=July 26, 2010|accessdate = March 19, 2013}}</ref>

=== Instant Answers ===
In addition to the indexed search results, DuckDuckGo displays relevant results, called Instant Answers,<ref>{{cite web|url = https://duck.co/ia|title = DuckDuckGo Instant Answers}}</ref> on top of the search page. These Instant Answers are collected from either 3rd party APIs or static data sources like text files. The Instant Answers are called ''zeroclickinfo'' because the intention behind these is to provide what the user is searching for on the search result page itself so that the user does not have to click any results to find what they are looking for. As of August 20, 2016, there are 989 Instant Answers active.

The Instant Answers are open source.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://github.com/duckduckgo/?utf8=%E2%9C%93&query=zeroclickinfo-|title = Instant Answer repositories on Github|accessdate = Jul 7, 2015}}</ref> They are maintained on Github and anyone can build or work on them.

=== Tor hidden service ===
In August 2010, DuckDuckGo introduced anonymous searching, including an exit enclave, for its search engine traffic using [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor network]] and enabling access through a [[Tor hidden service]]. This allows anonymity by routing traffic through a series of encrypted relays. Weinberg stated: "I believe this fits right in line with our privacy policy. Using Tor and DDG, you can now be end to end anonymous with your searching. And if you use our encrypted homepage, you can be end to end encrypted as well."{{cn|date=October 2017}}

=== Voice search ===
In 2011, DuckDuckGo introduced voice search for users of the [[Google Chrome]] [[voice search]] extension.<ref>[http://duckduckgo.com/tools.html "DuckDuckGo Tools"]. Duckduckgo.com {{dead link|date=September 2016}}</ref>

=== Bangs ===
DuckDuckGo includes "!Bang" keywords, which give users the ability to search on specific third-party websites – using the site's own search engine if applicable. As of 2017, approx. 10,000 "bangs" for a diverse range of Internet sites are available.<ref name="bang">{{cite web|url = https://duckduckgo.com/bang.html|title = !Bang |publisher = Duckduckgo.com |year = n.d. |accessdate = August 19, 2011}}</ref>

=== Privacy browser ===
DuckDuckGo has a mobile app available for [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] which forces websites to use [[HTTPS]], blocks web trackers, and rates sites based on their privacy practices.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/40519931/duckduckgo-moves-privacy-beyond-search-with-new-app-and-extension|title=DuckDuckGo Moves Privacy Beyond Search With New App And Extension|last=Melendez|first=Steven|date=23 January 2018|work=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]|access-date=27 January 2018}}</ref> The service, released in January 2018, is also available as a browser extension for [[Google Chrome]], [[Mozilla Firefox]], and [[Apple Safari]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2018/01/24/duckduckgo-tracker-blocker/|title=DuckDuckGo upgrades apps to block hidden ad trackers|last=Moon|first=Mariella|date=24 January 2018|work=[[Engadget]]|access-date=27 January 2018|publisher=[[Oath Inc.]]}}</ref>

=== Business model ===
DuckDuckGo earns revenue by serving ads from the Yahoo–Bing search alliance network, and through affiliate relationships with Amazon and eBay.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Advertising and Affiliates|url = https://duck.co/help/company/advertising-and-affiliates|website = DuckDuckGo Community Platform|accessdate = 2015-06-04}}</ref>

== Reception ==
In a June 2011 article, Harry McCracken of [[Time (magazine)|''Time'' magazine]] commended DuckDuckGo, comparing it to his favorite hamburger restaurant, [[In-N-Out Burger]]:
{{quote|It feels a lot like early Google, with a stripped-down home page. Just as In-N-Out doesn't have lattes or Asian salads or sundaes or scrambled eggs, DDG doesn't try to do news or blogs or books or images. There's no auto-completion or instant results. It just offers core Web search—mostly the "ten blue links" approach that's still really useful, no matter what its critics say...As for the quality, I'm not saying that Weinberg has figured out a way to return more relevant results than Google's mighty search team. But DuckDuckGo...is really good at bringing back useful sites. It all feels meaty and straightforward and filler-free...<ref name="McCracken16Jun11">{{Cite news|url=http://techland.time.com/2011/06/16/duck-duck-go-the-in-n-out-burger-of-search-engines/#ixzz1PXPmPOeK|title=Duck Duck Go, the In-N-Out Burger of Search Engines|last=McCracken|first=Harry|date=June 14, 2011|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|accessdate=March 19, 2013}}</ref>}} The barebones approach cited in his quote have since changed; DuckDuckGo now has auto-completion and instant results for example. McCracken included the site in ''Time'''s list of "50 Best Websites of 2011".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2087815_2088176_2088178,00.html|title=DuckDuckGo – The 50 Best Websites of 2011|work=Time|last=McCracken|first=Harry|date=August 16, 2011|accessdate=March 19, 2013}}</ref>

Thom Holwerda, who reviewed the search engine for ''[[OSNews]]'', praised its privacy features and shortcuts to site-specific searches as well as criticizing Google for "track[ing] pretty much everything you do", particularly because of the risk of such information being subject to a [[Federal government of the United States|U.S. government]] subpoena.<ref name="Holwerda21Jun11">{{Cite news|url=http://www.osnews.com/story/24867/DuckDuckGo_The_Privacy-centric_Alternative_to_Google|title=DuckDuckGo: The Privacy-centric Alternative to Google|date=June 21, 2011|last=Holwerda|first=Thom|publisher=[[OSNews]]|accessdate=March 19, 2013}}</ref> In 2012, in response to accusations that it was a monopoly, [[Google]] identified DuckDuckGo as a competitor. Weinberg was reportedly "pleased and entertained" by that acknowledgment.<ref name="WashPostNov2012" />

==Traffic==
{{Quote box|quote=It took 1445 days to get 1M searches,<br />483 days to get 2M searches,<br />and then just 8 days to pass 3M searches: https://duckduckgo.com/traffic/|source=DuckDuckGo [[Twitter]] account (@duckduckgo), 18 June 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/duckduckgo/status/347025281170694144 |title=Twitter / duckduckgo: It took 1445 days to get 1M ... |publisher=duckduckgo |date=18 June 2013 |accessdate=16 October 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Q7lsB9yv?url=https://twitter.com/duckduckgo/status/347025281170694144 |archivedate=6 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name=sel3m>{{cite web|url=http://searchengineland.com/duckduckgo-passes-3-million-searches-163846 |title=DuckDuckGo Passes 3 Million Searches, Just 8 Days After Hitting 2 Million |first=Matt |last=McGee |date=18 June 2013 |accessdate=12 October 2013 |publisher=[[Search Engine Land]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6KJF5mDJw?url=http://searchengineland.com/duckduckgo-passes-3-million-searches-163846 |archivedate=12 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name=nextweb3m>{{cite web
 |url=http://thenextweb.com/insider/2013/06/18/anonymous-search-engine-duckduckgo-hit-nearly-3-1-million-searches-yesterday-as-surveillance-fears-grow/ 
 |title=Google alternative DuckDuckGo hit nearly 3.1M queries yesterday, up 50% in 8 days as PRISM fears rise 
 |first=Harrison 
 |last=Weber 
 |publisher=The Next Web 
 |date=18 June 2013 
 |accessdate=12 October 2013 
 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6KJFJmlDa?url=http://thenextweb.com/insider/2013/06/18/anonymous-search-engine-duckduckgo-hit-nearly-3-1-million-searches-yesterday-as-surveillance-fears-grow/ 
 |archivedate=12 October 2013 
 |deadurl=yes 
 |df= 
}}</ref>|width=30%|align=right}}In June 2013, DuckDuckGo indicated that it had seen a significant traffic increase; according to the website's [[Twitter]] account, on Monday June 17, 2013, it had three million daily direct searches. On average during May 2013, it had 1.8 million daily direct searches. Some<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://libertyblitzkrieg.com/2013/07/10/search-engine-duck-duck-go-experiences-traffic-surge-in-wake-of-nsa-scandal/|title = Search Engine "Duck Duck Go" Experiences Traffic Surge in Wake of NSA Scandal|last = Krieger|first = Michael|date = Jul 10, 2013 <!-- at 11:25 am --> |work = Liberty Blitzkrieg|access-date = 7 March 2015}}</ref> relate this claim to the exposure of [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]] and to the fact that other programs operated by the [[National Security Agency]] (NSA) were leaked by [[Edward Snowden]]. [[Danny Sullivan (technologist)|Danny Sullivan]] wrote on ''Search Engine Land'' that despite the search engine's growth "it's not grown anywhere near the amount to reflect any substantial or even mildly notable switching by the searching public" for reasons due to privacy, and he concluded "No One Cares About "Private" Search".<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Danny Sullivan (technologist)|Sullivan, Danny]]|url=http://searchengineland.com/duck-duck-go-prism-private-search-164333|title=Duck Duck Go's Post-PRISM Growth Actually Proves No One Cares About "Private" Search|publisher=[[Search Engine Land]]|date=June 22, 2013|accessdate=July 10, 2013}}</ref> In response, Caleb Garling of the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' argued: "I think this thesis suffers from a few key failures in logic" because a traffic increase had occurred and because there was a lack of widespread awareness of the existence of DuckDuckGo.<ref>{{cite news|author= Garling, Caleb|url= http://blog.sfgate.com/techchron/2013/06/24/huge-traffic-spike-hits-private-search-engines-after-nsa-leaks/ |title=Huge traffic spike hits 'private' search engines after NSA leaks|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|date=June 24, 2013|accessdate= July 10, 2013}}</ref> Later in September 2013, the search engine hit 4 million searches per day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcworld.idg.com.au/article/528833/people_flock_anonymizing_services_after_nsa_snooping_reports/ |title=People flock to anonymizing services after NSA snooping reports |publisher=[[PCWorld|PCWorld Australia]] |first=Grant |last=Gross |date=10 October 2013 |accessdate=12 October 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6KJAq1wlV?url=http://www.pcworld.idg.com.au/article/528833/people_flock_anonymizing_services_after_nsa_snooping_reports/ |archivedate=12 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fiercecontentmanagement.com/story/duckduckgo-continues-making-huge-audience-gains/2013-09-16 |title=DuckDuckGo continues making huge audience gains |publisher=FierceContentManagement |first=Ron |last=Miller |date=16 September 2013 |accessdate=12 October 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6KJAsEgA1?url=http://www.fiercecontentmanagement.com/story/duckduckgo-continues-making-huge-audience-gains/2013-09-16 |archivedate=12 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.infoworld.com/t/web-services/duckduckgo-going-straight-226778 |title=DuckDuckGo going straight up |date=13 September 2013 |accessdate=12 October 2013 |first=Woody |last=Leonhard |publisher=[[InfoWorld]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6KJArzxxg?url=http://www.infoworld.com/t/web-services/duckduckgo-going-straight-226778 |archivedate=12 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> On March 23, 2015, DuckDuckGo retrieved more than 9 million searches for the first day in its history. That month also saw the search engine retrieve more than 250 million searches, another record for the company.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://duckduckgo.com/traffic.html|title=Traffic|date=3 April 2015|accessdate=6 April 2015|publisher=[[Duckduckgo]]}}</ref> In August 2017, the average number of queries per day was 16 million.<ref>https://duckduckgo.com/traffic.html</ref>
